resources.string: PM2.5 particles are small solid or liquid particles with a diameter of 2.5 microns or less. These particles are small enough to penetrate deeply into the lungs and can have serious health effects, especially for people with respiratory problems.
Similar to PM2.5 but with a size of up to 10 microns. Although they are not as small as PM2.5, they can still cause respiratory issues when inhaled.
Tropospheric ozone is a pollutant formed when nitrogen oxides (NOₓ) and volatile organic compounds (VOCs) react in the presence of sunlight. It can cause respiratory problems and affect vegetation.
It is a toxic gas that can cause irritation in the lungs. It is primarily formed from the burning of fossil fuels and is a precursor to tropospheric ozone.
This irritating gas can affect the respiratory system and contribute to the formation of acid rain. It is especially harmful to people with lung diseases.

An odorless and colorless gas that can be dangerous at high concentrations because it prevents the body from transporting oxygen properly. It can cause dizziness, fatigue, and in extreme cases, death.
It is a fine particulate pollutant produced by the incomplete combustion of fossil fuels and biomass. It contributes to climate change by absorbing sunlight and can affect respiratory health.

This colorless and odorless gas is a pollutant primarily formed from the burning of fossil fuels. While in small amounts it can play a role in regulating blood flow and blood pressure, in high concentrations it is toxic and can cause irritation in the eyes, nose, and throat, as well as respiratory problems. Additionally, nitric oxide can react in the atmosphere to form nitrogen dioxide (NO₂), a more harmful pollutant.
